content.description: A group of wombats is a wisdom. Begin up the vertical face under the left side of the large obvious roof to an awkward mantel. Climb through the roof with sharp crimps (crux), and once past the roof, easier terrain leads to the anchor.
content.location: This is the bolted line under the left side of the obvious roof.

content.description: A multiple wombat burrow is a warren. Begin up the face to a thin sequence before reaching the roof. Climb over the roof (crux) to the top. There is a small, but safe, easy runout to the anchor.
Did you know that wombats poop squares? Climb the face under the right side of the large, obvious roof. Climb out of the right side of the roof and then to the anchor.

Did you know that wombats can crush the skulls of dingos and Tasmanian devils with their ass? This climb requires thoughtful, sequential climbing. From the right edge of the formation, easy climbing leads to the first bolt. Although the second bolt may seem high, there is a great hold to make the reach. Crank through the crux (bolts 2-3), and reach easier climbing to the anchor.

Before mating, wombats will scratch and bite the ass of their partner; kinky. Climb the clean, vertical face to a small roof. Big reaches through the roof lead to some big jugs which lead to easier ground. The crux is between the second and third bolt.
content.location:
It is between

Wombat Wisdom

&

Backwards Pouch

.

content.description: To avoid digging dirt on their young, the marsupial wombat's pouch faces backwards. Begin just right of a tree on the left side of the crag. Interesting face climbing leads to a small bulge. Continue past the bulge to a good stance, and then motor up featured slab to the anchor. The route is sustained at the grade, and it's too bad it isn't longer!
content.location: This is the furthest left bolted line at the crag.
